data.description:
# The open collaboration protocol built on Base. Co-create, attest, and own your collaboration graph, forever.

# Open to the Public (OTTP) is on a mission to democratize innovation.

![Current State to Future State](https://i.imgur.com/ktAPsPf.png)


# Problem

**Siloed:** Your contributions are siloed in various communities/projects, and if they sunset, your contributions are lost.

**Self-reported:** Contributions are self-reported and unverified.

**Platform-controlled:** Your contributions are locked into closed platforms, such as LinkedIn and GitHub.


# Solution

**Interconnected:** Your contributions are recognized and attributed. If the community/project sunsets, you have the ability to prove who you worked with and what you did together.

**Collaborator-verified:** Contributions are verified by collaborators and/or the community via onchain attestations.

**Self-custodial:** Your collaboration graph is owned by you. You can move freely between apps/clients.

Through onchain attestations, users build social trust as they gain verifiable contributions to projects.

The protocol is not owned by a central entity. It is accessible and open to everyone, so developers can innovate and build with the shared dataset. 


# Progress

We participated in the Open Source category of **Backdrop Build V3** and was selected as one of the finalists. [Watch demo video.](https://backdropbuild.com/builds/v3/open-to-the-public) 

During the four weeks, we went from zero to live protocol. We created the backend code and smart contracts and launched a **Farcaster Frame** and attestation bot. People use their Farcaster ID to create an OTTP ID and grow their collaboration graphs by making onchain attestations. [Get collaboration graph.](https://warpcast.com/ottp/0xfab58542)

![Attestation Frame](https://i.imgur.com/sWudkIT.gif)

![Verification Frame](https://i.imgur.com/WSBmVXP.gif)

**Core Features:**
- OTTP ID
- Sign in with Farcaster ID (FID)
- User profiles
- Attestations

**Core Features (in progress | coming soon):**
- SDK
- Sign in with other methods, e.g. wallet, email, Lens
- Account recovery
- Account-abstracted wallets
- Usernames
- OTTP Org ID
- Community/org profiles
- Project pages
- Proposal pages
- Comments
- Upvote/downvote
- Token-gating

We're currently connecting with partners to integrate or build apps/clients with OTTP.

With the support of this grant, we will be able to cover operational costs, e.g. retroactive compensation to open-source devs, continued development, and bounties.

# Tech Stack

- [Base](https://base.org)
- [Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS)](https://attest.org)
- [Farcaster](https://farcaster.xyz)
- [GraphQL](https://graphql.org)
- [Next.js](https://nextjs.org)
- [Neynar](https://neynar.com) 
- [Node.js](https://nodejs.org)


# Links

- [Website](https://opentothepublic.org)
- [Documentation](https://ottp.gitbook.io/docs)
- [Github Repo](https://github.com/opentothepublic/protocol)
- [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ottp__)
- Farcaster: [Warpcast](https://warpcast.com/ottp)
- Community: [Warpcast Channel](https://warpcast.com/~/channel/ottp)
- Lens: [Hey](https://hey.xyz/u/ottp__)
- [Zora Collection](https://zora.co/collect/base:0x56f1976473a6014946e280994b045e7176b2884e)


# Contributors

- [Nate](https://twitter.com/nathansvan)
- [Ting](https://twitter.com/ting)
- [Krish](https://twitter.com/lowcodekrish)
- [Peter](https://twitter.com/PeterAnyaogu)
data.title: Open to the Public

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.

questions.query: How is the project CollabTech?
questions.explanation:
We have been building Open to the Public since the beginning of the year, and collaboration is the core of our vision and protocol. 

Currently, collaborative contributions are locked into platforms like LinkedIn and GitHub. With OTTP, users own their graph and can freely transfer it across applications, enabling ownership, recognition, and open collaboration for all. 

We need a better way to give new projects a try, to simply gather around a vision for a project with the people and capital necessary to bring it to life. Accessible infrastructure opens opportunities for people to easily participate, co-create with others, be recognized, and share in the upside.

questions.query: Who's the targeted user group and what's the need/problem being addressed?
questions.explanation:
Currently, builders choose between accelerators, vying for social media visibility, cold DMing investors, bootstrapping, buying into founder communities, and often left without credit for their contributions when the project doesn’t work out.

Contributors choose between job applications, trying to network their way deeper into community, doing free work without guaranteed credit, or buying into projects to get involved.

These user groups are ideally suited to use the OTTP client:
- Onchain communities that want to give verifiable credit to community members for their contributions.
- Those who want to create projects for anyone to contribute to, such as open-source public goods, open projects serving the needs of a community, or open projects to complement for-profit businesses. 
- Builders who are already creating work-related or collaboration apps, to fork aspects of our web client to incorporate OTTP features within their own apps or integrate the SDK.

questions.query: How do you ensure value keeps being delivered after the round is over? (How will the project become commercially sustainable or a perennial good? )
questions.explanation:
OTTP unlocks the opportunity for many different groups to create for-profit entities on top of the open-source protocol. We believe, just as with other open-source standards, that for-profit companies will have a motive to invest in its continued maintenance and development to continue to push the protocol forward.

As the protocol grows and more clients are built on it, a governance structure can be put in place to keep it democratic, fair, and transparent.

questions.query: How long will it take after funding is received to deliver value? (share a high level timeline)
questions.explanation:
*0-2 weeks*
- Deploy new version of smart contract and test backend.
- Update the SDK.

*3-5 weeks*
- Develop a web client, allowing users to create projects and attest to contributions onchain. Open to initial testers.

*5-8 Weeks*
- Add additional features, such as proposals. Open to everyone to use.
- Release SDK v2.

questions.query: Project GitHub Repo
questions.explanation: https://github.com/opentothepublic/contracts | https://github.com/opentothepublic/ottp-web-client | https://github.com/opentothepublic/ottp-sdk

questions.query: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile to prior rounds.
questions.explanation: https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/round/42161/26/78

questions.query: How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
Farcaster (on OP stack) and Lens (on Polygon) are tackling the social graph. We are progressively decentralizing the work graph. We’re focused on creating the standard for collaboration and making it accessible and open to everyone.

OTTP ID: This is like a resident ID/social security number that is unique to the user.
ORG ID: This is like a business ID/employer identification number that is unique to the organization.


These IDs are owned by the individual and organization, respectively. It’s the onchain connector that links your network and contributions together.


Imagine a world where a project attestation is not only verifiably linked to social profiles (like Farcaster and Lens) but also grants they have received from Gitcoin, Optimism, hackathons, accelerators, etc. And even further, we want to enable use of the same project page across multiple clients, such as Gitcoin and Optimism.


We are building OTTP for many use cases related to collaboration. Project attestations created by an individual (or an organization) would be linked to their OTTP ID and connected to any social accounts, previous projects or contributions. A project page could be repurposed anywhere and connected to anything else on the open protocol. Anything related to work/collaboration that can be proven onchain, connected together through the OTTP ID into a collaboration graph.


Our SDK v1 has received 1K+ downloads to date.

Once we have more data, we want to have a Dune dashboard. For now, these are the metrics we’re tracking.

Number of unique users (accounts created)
Number of attestations made
Number of verified contributions
Number of verified collaborators
Average number of attestations per account

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation:
We’re building accessible infrastructure that is not only interoperable and user-friendly, but one that is truly multiplayer for individuals and teams.

With the open protocol, people get their contributions verified by collaborators via onchain attestations and are able to move freely between apps/clients.


OTTP protocol design using onchain attestations:
Subjects: identities who take actions
Objects: containers created by subjects
Blocks: object subcomponents created by subjects
Links: verified connections between subjects and objects

Any subject (individual or team) can create an object. To start, there are four object types: Project, Proposal, Milestone, and Contribution. Blocks are subcomponents that can point to onchain or off-chain data (files, images, links, etc.). Every link (connection) between subjects and/or objects can be verified by an onchain attestation.

Note: Visuals are included on our project page.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation:
People’s digital identities are tied to their wallet, and in most cases, a single wallet. By enabling account abstraction and multiple wallet connections, people and organizations can share a holistic footprint across chains if they choose to.

The Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS) enables anyone to attest to anything. We are adding the work layer on top for anyone to attest to any collaboration; to put their work onchain.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
Q4 2024: work in progress:
Release SDK v2, including sign in with Ethereum address (currently sign in with Farcaster), ORG ID, interoperable objects and blocks
Release web client v0
Update Farcaster frame for cast action or composer action

Q1 2025: 
Add account recovery
Add account-abstracted wallets
Add comments
Add upvote/downvote

We are raising funds for the continued development of the open protocol, including an updated SDK. We will use 100% of the funds for development, mostly in the form of public bounties. We are dependent on open-source developers.

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation:
By creating a more decentralized and self-sovereign system for managing work contributions and collaborations, it reduces reliance on centralized platforms.

We want people to have control. No matter if they want some centralized safeguards or if they’re decentralized maxis, the choice is theirs.
How they login: Farcaster, Lens, email, or wallet. People can connect their social graph or not.
How they recover their account
What they display on their profile
What apps/clients they want to use
What communities/organizations they identify with or contribute to


We want organizations to be built for collaboration. Multiplayer-mode enabled.
How contributors login
How they recover their account
What they display their profile
What apps/clients do they want to build
What contributors do they want to attest to

questions.query: For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.
questions.explanation: N/A
